blog.name: supinternets
blog.title: Hello Internet
blog.description:
Welcome to my tumblr.

My name is Amanda. I am graphic designer and free lance artist. I live in Tallahassee, Fl with my husband Mike and our pack of chihuahuas. I love mid century modern design, sci-fi, animation, stand up comedy, Doctor Who, home projects, subverting the dominant paradigm, anime and philosophy. I'm what you might call a renaissance woman.

Prepare for randomness and geekery.

ABOUT ME

BUY MY ART

TAGS

"MY ART"My Doctor Who fanartTHINGS I MADE AKA MINEDOCTOR WHOCARL SAGAN

blog.name: hammaclet
blog.title: HamMaclet
blog.description: Prince of Denmark, King of Scotland - the adventure of a Shakespeare fan (who apparently likes the tragedies). Hamlet is my favourite Shakes play, but MacBeth was my first and will always hold a special place in my heart.

summary:
Act IV - The Deposition Scene - aka the “HEEEEEEEEEERE COUSIN” scene (or the come and take it scene). 
David Tennant about the...
body:
Act IV - The Deposition Scene - aka the “HEEEEEEEEEERE COUSIN” scene (or the come and take it scene).

David Tennant about the Deposition Scene of Richard II in the talk at the Barbican on January 16th, 2016

“And it’s an awful, dawning, heart-stopping sickness to realise: The angels aren’t coming.”

“God doesn’t show up with his host of heavenly angels. And that must be a terrible, terrible realisation. Someone who all his life has been told he’s God’s representative on earth, and has ‘believed’ that. And I think he genuinely believed that if it comes to it, that the angels will descend from heaven and fight off Bolingbroke.

“Actually, there is a very clever, very witty, very powerful man, who only kind of discovers how powerful he is when he’s lost it all. Because it’s only really in that scene that he shows great leadership in a sense. It’s only in that scene that he can manipulate people to do everything he needs them to do.

“The angels aren’t coming. And actually it’s just down to you. And I think that that is perhaps where the performance that he does begin to muster in the deposition scene comes from. A sense of ‘Oh, I’ve got to fight my own battles now.’ And actually, he does it rather well. He’s at his finest in the deposition scene. Having lost all of his power, he has complete control of that room, and he has everyone in the palm of his hand. And there is a tragedy in that.”

reblog.comment:

David Tennant about the Deposition Scene of Richard II in the talk at the Barbican on January 16th, 2016

And I think he genuinely believed that if it comes to it, that the angels will descend from heaven and fight off Bolingbroke.

“Actually, there is a very clever, very witty, very powerful man, who only kind of discovers how powerful he is when he’s lost it all. Because it’s only really in that scene that he shows great leadership in a sense. It’s only in that scene that he can manipulate people to do everything he needs them to do.

“The angels aren’t coming. And actually it’s just down to you. And I think that that is perhaps where the performance that he does begin to muster in the deposition scene comes from. A sense of ‘Oh, I’ve got to fight my own battles now.’ And actually, he does it rather well. He’s at his finest in the deposition scene. Having lost all of his power, he has complete control of that room, and he has everyone in the palm of his hand. And there is a tragedy in that.”

“God doesn’t show up with his host of heavenly angels. And that must be a terrible, terrible realisation. Someone who all his life has been told he’s God’s representative on earth, and has ‘believed’ that. “Actually, there is a very clever, very witty, very powerful man, who only kind of discovers how powerful he is when he’s lost it all. Because it’s only really in that scene that he shows great leadership in a sense. It’s only in that scene that he can manipulate people to do everything he needs them to do.

“The angels aren’t coming. And actually it’s just down to you. And I think that that is perhaps where the performance that he does begin to muster in the deposition scene comes from. A sense of ‘Oh, I’ve got to fight my own battles now.’ And actually, he does it rather well. He’s at his finest in the deposition scene. Having lost all of his power, he has complete control of that room, and he has everyone in the palm of his hand. And there is a tragedy in that.”
trail.content:

David Tennant about the Deposition Scene of Richard II in the talk at the Barbican on January 16th, 2016

Someone who all his life has been told he’s God’s representative on earth, and has ‘believed’ that. “Actually, there is a very clever, very witty, very powerful man, who only kind of discovers how powerful he is when he’s lost it all. tags: it's always lovely to read the wonderful things people have to say about david
I cannot believe that this is post 20 for this episode
summary: Behind the Scenes of The Christmas Invasion (Part 20)  Excerpts from Doctor Who: The Inside Story: Having forged this excellent...
caption:
Behind the Scenes of The Christmas Invasion (Part 20)

Excerpts from Doctor Who: The Inside Story:

Having forged this excellent team of player for the first series, it became necessary to start the search for a new Doctor. Enter a young Scots actor called David McDonald, better known these days as David Tennant.

“David’s always been one of my favorite actors,” says Andy Pryor [casting director]. “I’ve seen a lot of his theatre work and he’s really got one of the most expansive ranges of any British actor I know - he can do almost anything and, although it’s often said, that isn’t really true of that many actors. David can do strength, vulnerability, he can be sexy, funny; he can do pretty much anything you ask him to do. It was a brilliant piece of timing really, because Casanova and Blackpool had just happened, so he was becoming a household name. Not that we felt it absolutely necessary for the Doctor to be a household name, but the fact that he was in people’s consciousness and had recently demonstrated that he could carry a drama on his own and be a strong leading man was perfect timing. There was no competition and no discussion about who else it might be. We all agreed one hundred percent that it should be David right from the word go. No one else was ever seen or thought about.”

Other parts of this photoset: [one] [two] [three] [four] [five] [six] [seven] [eight] [nine] [ten] [eleven] [twelve] [thirteen] [fourteen] [fifteen] [sixteen] [seventeen] [eighteen] [nineteen]
[ List of all Doctor Who Behind the Scenes photosets ]
